answers.feedback: The temperature increase will result in a change in reactivity of: -2.5 × 10-4 ΔK/K/C × 50C = -1.25 × 10-2 ΔK/K. Since the temperature rise results in a negative reactivity insertion, the control rod will need to drive out to add positive reactivity. D = (1.25 × 10-2 ΔK/K) ÷ (5.895 × 10-3 ΔK/K/inch) = 2.12 inches

question: A reactor is subcritical with a Keff of 0.955. A positive reactivity of 3.5% delta k/k is inserted into the core. At this point, the reactor is:

answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Page 4-8.

answers.answer: b. increases because prompt neutrons are being produced at a faster rate.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Page 4-8.

answers.answer: c. increases because delayed neutron precursors are being produced at a faster rate.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Page 4-8.

answers.answer: d. decreases because delayed neutrons are being produced from precursors that were formed at a lower power level.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Page 4-8.

question: During the time when reactor power increases, the delayed neutron fraction, β:

answers.answer: a. DRW relates the worth of the rod per increment of movement to rod position. IRW relates the total reactivity added by the rod to rod position.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 7-1 thru 7-5.

answers.answer: b. DRW relates the time rate of reactivity change to rod position. IRW relates the total reactivity in the core to the time rate of reactivity change.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 7-1 thru 7-5.

answers.answer: c. IRW relates the worth of the rod per increment of movement to rod position. DRW relates the total reactivity added by the rod to rod position.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 7-1 thru 7-5.

answers.answer: d. IRW is the slope of the DRW at a given rod position.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 7-1 thru 7-5.

question: Which ONE of the following statements describes the difference between Differential Rod Worth (DRW) and Integral Rod Worth (IRW)?

answers.answer: a. Neutron flux will be higher for the first startup.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 5-14 thru 5-19.

answers.answer: b. Neutron flux will be higher for the second startup.
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 5-14 thru 5-19.

answers.answer: c. The first startup will result in a higher rod position (rods further out of the core).
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 5-14 thru 5-19.

answers.answer: d. The second startup will result in a higher rod position (rods further out of the core).
answers.feedback: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Pages 5-14 thru 5-19.
